context: In the late 1980s, according to "Richard Feynman and the Connection Machine", Feynman played a crucial role in developing the first <b5_0>massively <a0_0>parallel computer<b5_0/><a0_0/>, and in finding innovative uses for it in numerical computations, in building neural networks, as well as physical simulations using cellular automata (such as turbulent fluid flow), working with <a1_0><b6_0>Stephen Wolfram<b6_0/><a1_0/> at Caltech. <a2_0><b7_0>His son Carl<b7_0/><a2_0/> also played a role in the development of the original Connection Machine engineering; Feynman <a4_0><b9_0>influencing the interconnects<b9_0/><a4_0/> while his son worked on the <a3_0><b8_0>software<b8_0/><a3_0/>.
